meaning_mnemonic: This radical looks like a hat with some legs under it. If all you can see is legs, the person wearing the hat must really be <radical>jammed in</radical> there. Have you ever tried to cram yourself into a hat so hard it covers your body? Yeah, didn't think so. But imagine how jammed in to that hat you'd be if you did.

This is the <radical>history</radical> radical. You can see a textbook and a couple crossed swords. Because that's basically how history works — fight battles, record the results, and do it all over again. History!

Kind of a strange <radical>tent</radical>, I'll admit, but one that will protect you from things trying to get in (that's why it has all the spikes). It's the best you can do, considering you're in a cloth tent.

A <radical>clown</radical> face, with the funny hat at the top, the silly eyes in the middle, and the big laughing mouth at the bottom. This thing is pretty cute, unlike a lot of clowns…

You could also see this as the stand radical on top of the mouth radical, since standing on their mouth is the kind of weird trick a clown would do.

This radical looks like a curvy letter B. What does B stand for? <radical>Building</radical>! This radical often shows up in kanji related to gatherings or to places where people come together… like buildings.

This is the <radical>spicy</radical> radical. See how it's wide at the top, with a little stem sticking up, and narrow at the bottom? Just like a chili pepper. It's so spicy it can't even handle its own heat!

This is the <radical>heavy</radical> radical. See the square fist in the center, grasping the handle of a dumbbell that has two heavy plates on the top and bottom? The radical just looks like it would be heavy, you know?

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>anti</radical>.

Just in case you don't remember this, here's the kanji meaning mnemonic: The <radical>stool</radical> is in the <radical>cliff</radical>. If someone has a stool deep inside a cliff, they are most likely pretty <kanji>anti</kanji> society, hiding away like that.
This radical kind of looks like a <radical>brush</radical>. The top part is a hand holding the brush handle, and the bottom part is the bristly tip.

You're lost, but you've come across a signpost that says "<radical>correct</radical>" in all directions. "Correct," "correct," "correct," it says. No matter which way you go, it's the correct way! What a relief!

You could also use the mnemonic you learned with the kanji: There is a line on the ground so you stop, making a giant sign pop up that says CORRECT! You obeyed the rules of the road and did the correct thing. Good on you.

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>machine</radical>.

Just in case you don't remember this, here's the kanji meaning mnemonic: You have a <radical>private</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> that's a <kanji>machine</kanji>. But you have to keep your machine mouth private because it would scare all the non-machine people around you.

See all the arms sticking out of this radical? Those are for hanging lots of coats and things on, because this is a <radical>coat rack</radical>. Kind of a weird coat rack, but definitely a coat rack.

This radical looks like a <radical>helicopter</radical> coming straight at you, doesn't it? You can't see the tail part because it's behind the bigger front cab of the helicopter. But you can see the front windows and the big spinning blade on top.

There's the bottom of a shoe with spikes coming out of it. Only one kind of shoe is like this, and that's a <radical>cleat</radical>. You know, like those studded shoes athletes wear. Soccer cleats, baseball cleats, running cleats… You knew they were called cleats, right?

This is the <radical>spring</radical> radical, because it looks like a new plant shoot has pushed its way up through layers of dirt, snow, and ice to announce the coming of spring. Spring is the season (and the radical) full of new, growing life!
See the <radical>squid</radical> shape here? There's its pointy head, its eyes, and its tentacles (two, anyway). Pretty squid-like if you ask me!

There's a canopy with a grid-like frame near the top. It's a <radical>yurt</radical> with a window! Yurts are those dome-shaped huts nomads use. Once you've set up a canopy with a window frame, you've basically built one. Imagine gazing out that window, kicking back in your yurt. Yurt sweet yurt!

Someone shoved horns onto your husband and said he has to fight for them now. They turned him into a <radical>gladiator</radical>! Now your husband has to fight for their amusement. Are you not entertained?!

P.S. You know this is a gladiator, not a viking, because the horns are on the gladiator's shoulder pads instead of his helmet, and his helmet has a big crest on it.

A drop of water will last for an <radical>eternity</radical>. Especially if you drop it into an endless stream that never stops flowing. You can see these streams converging from all directions here, flowing for eternity.
